content.text: Welcome to the Albert Cuypmarkt in Amsterdam! You're about to order a 'stroopwafel', a famous Dutch treat. A fresh one from a market is an unforgettable experience.

data.tip: The 'g' sound in Dutch is made in the back of your throat. It's similar to the 'ch' in the Scottish word 'loch'.

content.text: 'Ik wil graag' is a polite and common way to order things in Dutch. It's more polite than just saying 'Ik wil' (I want).

data.tip: The 'oo' sounds like the 'oa' in 'boat'. The 'w' is soft, like a 'v' sound.

content.title: Milestone 1: Place Your Order
content.setting: You're at a busy stroopwafel stall. The air smells sweet. The vendor smiles at you, ready to take your order.

content.text: 'Alstublieft' is very versatile. You use it when you give something ('Here you are') and when you ask for something ('Please').

content.title: Milestone 2: Confirm and Pay
content.setting: The vendor nods after hearing your order and starts preparing your stroopwafel. Now it's time to handle the payment.

conversation_flow.title: Ask for the price.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Oké, één verse stroopwafel. Komt eraan!

conversation_flow.title: Say you will pay with cash.
Say 'Here you are' as you hand over the money.

content.text: 'Dank je wel' is a very common and friendly way to say thank you. You can also use the shorter 'dank je'.

data.tip: This literally means 'Until seeing'. It's a common, slightly formal way to say goodbye.

content.title: Milestone 3: Receive and Depart
content.setting: You've paid. The vendor hands you a warm, fresh stroopwafel wrapped in paper. It smells delicious.

conversation_flow.title: Take the stroopwafel and say thank you.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Alstublieft, een warme stroopwafel. Eet smakelijk!
